revision.text: {{talkheader}} {{ArticleHistory |action1=GAN |action1date=22:27, 13 October 2011 (UTC) |action1link=Talk:Dunster Castle/GA1 |action1result=listed |action1oldid=455444645 |action2=GTC |action2date=18:00, 6 December 2015 (UTC) |action2link=Wikipedia:Featured topic candidates/National Trust properties in Somerset/archive1 |action2result=promoted |ftname=National Trust properties in Somerset |topic=War and military |currentstatus=GA }} {{WikiProjectBannerShell|1= {{WPMILHIST |class=GA |A-Class= |B-Class-1=y |B-Class-2=y |B-Class-3=y |B-Class-4=y |B-Class-5=y |Fortifications-task-force=yes |British-task-force= yes |Medieval-task-force= yes |Early-Modern-task-force= yes }} {{WPE|class=GA|importance=mid}} {{WikiProject Somerset|class=GA|importance=mid}} {{WikiProject Museums|class=GA|importance=low}} {{WikiProject Architecture|historic-houses=yes|class=GA}} }} == Red Sandstone disambiguation == A "disambiguation needed" tag has been placed on the mentions of [[Red Sandstone]]. I would speculate that this should be Triassic [[New Red Sandstone]] from the location of the castle & distributions of the rock. [http://www.naturalengland.org.uk/Images/jca144_tcm6-5549.pdf This source (p138)] says "The Triassic red sandstone of the Quantock Hills..... has been widely used in the area ...The larger manor houses and mansions which lie around the edge of the area, like Nettlecombe Court, Combe Sydenham and Dunster Castle. However [http://www.archaeology.demon.co.uk/3363-1-2.pdf this document (p8)] talks about the geology being [[Old Red Sandstone]]. Any help or alternative sources would be helpful.— [[User:Rodw|Rod]] [[User talk:Rodw|talk]] 17:23, 11 October 2011 (UTC) :I'd be tempted to change it from "[[red sandstone]]" to "red [[sandstone]]". [[User:Nev1|Nev1]] ([[User talk:Nev1|talk]]) 17:26, 11 October 2011 (UTC) ::I've had this problem on another article - I'm with Rod that it is probably New Red Sandstone, but in the absence of a hard ref, I'd be inclined to play it safe as per Nev's suggestion. [[User:Hchc2009|Hchc2009]] ([[User talk:Hchc2009|talk]]) 17:34, 11 October 2011 (UTC) :(e/c with Hchc2009) Apologies for the tagging; I fixed a few things but couldn't work out the best one here. [[Old red sandstone]] at least appears to be in the right geographical area as compared to [[new red sandstone]], according to that most reliable of sources Wikipedia (see those articles and also [[Geology of Somerset]](!)). Natural England calls it "old red sandstone" in that article you link, Rodw, and also [http://www.naturalengland.org.uk/ourwork/conservation/geodiversity/englands/counties/area_ID30.aspx here], but I don't know why it also describes it as "Triassic", which would point to New (unless I'm missing something). [http://www.soton.ac.uk/~imw/jpg/stdormap.jpg This map] (from [http://www.soton.ac.uk/~imw/Field-Guides-Introduction.htm Southampton University Earth Sciences dept]) has "old red sandstone" in the vicinity rather than "new". [http://www.westsomersetmineralrailway.org.uk/EasySiteWeb/getresource.axd?AssetID=8314&type=full&servicetype=Attachment This map] has "new" quite close to Dunster. As I'm no geologist and my knowledge of Somerset is limited to cricket, Nev's suggestion looks good... [[User:Bencherlite|Bencherlite]][[User talk:Bencherlite|Talk]] 17:53, 11 October 2011 (UTC) ::Thanks to all for contributions. I think Nev's suggestion may be the best option particularly as in the 15th century (as the article says) "imported Bristol red sandstone" was used. Therefore local geology may be no indicator, and the stone used for building may be different from the mound it is built on mentioned in Note 1.— [[User:Rodw|Rod]] [[User talk:Rodw|talk]] 18:05, 11 October 2011 (UTC)
